title.native: 交響詩篇エウレカセブン

description:
Renton is a teenager trapped working as a mechanic in a backwater town. He dreams of joining up with a daredevil group of pilots known as Gekkostate and following in his father's heroic footsteps.

When a mysterious beauty named Eureka shows up asking for a tune-up, Renton soon finds himself drawn into a high-flying mecha dogfight that makes him a target of the military. When the dust settles on the spectacular battle, Renton is invited to join Gekkostate, but he soon discovers that even a dream come true has a dark side.

(Source: Funimation)

tags.name: Environmental
tags.description: Concern with the state of the natural world and how humans interact with it.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Politics
tags.description: Centers around politics, politicians, or government activities.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Surfing
tags.description: Centers around surfing as a sport.

tags.name: Found Family
tags.description: Features a group of characters with no biological relations that are united in a group providing social support.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Terrorism
tags.description: Centers around the activities of a terrorist or terrorist organization.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Aviation
tags.description: Regarding the flying or operation of aircraft.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Aliens
tags.description: Prominently features extraterrestrial lifeforms.

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Clone
tags.description: Prominently features a character who is an artificial exact copy of another organism.

tags.name: Ships
tags.description: Prominently features the use of sea-based transportation vessels.

tags.name: Tanned Skin
tags.description: Prominently features characters with tanned skin.

tags.name: Unrequited Love
tags.description: One or more characters are experiencing an unrequited love that may or may not be reciprocated.

tags.name: Parenthood
tags.description: Centers around the experience of raising a child.

tags.name: Cohabitation
tags.description: Features two or more people who live in the same household and develop a romantic or sexual relationship.

tags.name: Football
tags.description: Centers around the sport of football (known in the USA as "soccer").

tags.name: Nudity
tags.description: Features a character wearing no clothing or exposing intimate body parts.

tags.name: Suicide
tags.description: The act or an instance of taking or attempting to take one's own life voluntarily and intentionally.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

node.description: Rafael Antonio "Tony" Olivier is a Puerto Rican-born American voice actor best known for voicing Rick Hunter from Robotech, Lancer from Fate/stay night, and Arsène Lupin III from Lupin the Third. He helped produce the live action shows Mighty Morphin Power Rangers and VR Troopers.

Shouji Kawamori is an anime creator, director and mechanical designer. Also a current advisor for [Satelight](https://anilist.co/studio/41/).

Famous for his work in the [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1088/) and Transformers franchises. He pioneered several innovative concepts in his works, such as transforming mecha (including the VF-1 Valkyrie in Macross and Optimus Prime in Transformers) and virtual idols (including Lynn Minmay and Sharon Apple in the Macross franchise).

Kawamori attended Keio University together with Macross screenwriter [Hiroshi Oonogi](https://anilist.co/staff/97701/) and character designer [Haruhiko Mikimoto](https://anilist.co/staff/96968/). There they became friends and founded a [Mobile Suit Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/80/) fan club called "Gunsight One," a name the group would use years later during the development of the fictional world of the Macross series. Later on his career Kawamori created or co-created the concepts which served as basis for several anime series. His projects are usually noted to contain strong themes of love, war, spirituality or mysticism, and ecological concern.

Kawamori also helped to design various toys for the Takara toyline, Diaclone in the early '80s. Among them the first Optimus Prime toy design, Prowl, Bluestreak, Smokescreen, Ironhide, and Ratchet. Over 20 years later, he returned to Transformers by designing both the Hybrid Style Convoy and the Masterpiece version of Starscream for Takara.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/naokisato_face) | [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/1hlpldRj6GZ2naD4XDqi80)

Naoki Sato is a Japanese composer and producer who has provided the music for several popular anime series. He was born on May 2, 1970 and graduated in Chiba Prefecture and Tokyo College of Music. At the 29th Japanese Academy Awards in 2006, he won the Best Music prize for his work on the film Always Sanchōme no Yuhi.
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐藤大)

__[Website](http://www.flow-official.jp/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCLakaKEelmUdqQISLjwIRmg)__ | __[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/FLOWofficial.music)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/FLOW_official)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/FLOW_OFFICIAL_JAPAN/)__

FLOW is a Japanese rock band that formed in 1998 and is signed on to Sony Music Japan's Ki/oon Records label. Flow is a five-piece band made up of two vocalists, a drummer, a bassist and a guitarist.

__Members:__
- [Keigo Hayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/227206/Keigo) (林圭吾) | KEIGO  - Vocalist
- [Kohshi Asakawa](https://anilist.co/staff/160032) (浅川甲史) | KOHSHI - Vocalist, Occasional rhythm guitarist
- [Takeshi Asakawa](https://anilist.co/staff/160033) (浅川岳史) | TAKE  - Lead Guitarist
- Hiroshi Iwasaki | IWASAKI (岩崎博詞) - Drummer
- Yasutaro Gotou | GOT'S (後藤康太郎) - Bass

__[Website](http://www.flow-official.jp/)__ | __[YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCLakaKEelmUdqQISLjwIRmg)__ | __[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/FLOWofficial.music)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/FLOW_official)__ | __[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/FLOW_OFFICIAL_JAPAN/)__

FLOW is a Japanese rock band that formed in 1998 and is signed on to Sony Music Japan's Ki/oon Records label. Flow is a five-piece band made up of two vocalists, a drummer, a bassist and a guitarist.

__Members:__
- [Keigo Hayashi](https://anilist.co/staff/227206/Keigo) (林圭吾) | KEIGO  - Vocalist
- [Kohshi Asakawa](https://anilist.co/staff/160032) (浅川甲史) | KOHSHI - Vocalist, Occasional rhythm guitarist

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/tomoki_kyoda/)

Influenced by Hiroyuki Nakano's commercials and music videos, he studied video art at the Musashino Art University, joining Gento Matsumoto's company Sal Brunei as a graphic designer. He soon changed his occupation to the animation industry, having aspired to be an animation director since his childhood. 

He initially joined [Group TAC](https://anilist.co/studio/86/Group-TAC) where he worked as episode director and storyboard artist under the guidance of [Mitsuru Hongou](https://anilist.co/staff/103366/Mitsuru-Hongou). His first major role was as mechanical/creature designer on [Chikyuu Bouei Kazoku](https://anilist.co/anime/1962/The-Daichis--Earths-Defense-Family/), working alongside [Shouji Kawamori](https://anilist.co/staff/97501/Shouji-Kawamori) and [Kazutaka Miyatake](https://anilist.co/staff/100987/Kazutaka-Miyatake), with whom he would collaborate profusely afterwards. 

He later moved to studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/bones) landing as assistant director for [Yutaka Izubuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/99075/Yutaka-Izubuchi)'s [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/RahXephon/). The two became close collaborators, with Kyouda soon taking the leading role on the [RahXephon: Pluralitas Concentio](https://anilist.co/anime/758/RahXephon-The-Motion-Picture/) movie.

Soon after, he directed [Eureka Seven](https://anilist.co/anime/237/Eureka-Seven/), incorporating his love for music and different sub-cultures into mecha anime.

Nirgilis is a Japanese electronic rock band formed in 1993 by Moyo Satake and Takeshi Ito. Acchu Iwata, Minoru Kurihara, and Yuki Inadera joined in 1995. Satake and Ito left the group in 2004 and 2007, respectively, leaving the group without its founders.  (Source: Wikipedia)

__[Website](https://www.home-made.jp/)__ | __[Twitter](https://twitter.com/HMKU_Official)__ | __[Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/HomeMadeKazokuOfficial/)__

__Introduction:__
Home Made Kazoku (stylized HOME MADE Kazoku) was a three member hip-hop trio signed under record label Ki/oon Records, a subsidiary of Sony Music. The band was originally created in 1996 under a different name and went through many members before finally settling on being a trio with the name Home Made Kazoku in 2001.

__Biography:__
The trio have since their proper establishment in 2001, released 11 albums, 15 compilation albums, 27 singles and 7 DVDs (containing live-concerts, home made films, etc). From 2001 to 2003, the band performed in various Nagoya nightclubs, while in early 2004 the band was chosen to be a part of a country-wide tour known as the Japan Club Tour. During the tour, the trio garned a large portion of their Japanese fanbase, and were also able to get signed to record company Ki/oon Records.

The vocalists Micro (stylized as MICRO) and Kuro (stylized as KURO) are both originally from the United States. Micro spent a portion of his childhood in Kentucky, while Kuro said that he lived in Chicago, Illinois until he was twelve years old.

Shortly after being signed by a record company, the group released an album containing the song "Home Sweet Home (Reborn.)" which became one of the most requested songs on Japanese radio stations for the rest of the year 2004, later in July of the same year, Home Made Kazoku released their first single "Summer Time Magic". This single ranked 15th on the Oricon record charts for nearly 10 weeks straight.

After a series of single releases, including "[Thank You!!](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BvYuf4r-8xk)", which was used as the second ending theme to the largely popular shounen anime [Bleach](https://anilist.co/anime/269/Bleach/), while their song "[Shounen Heart](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgAifYag2_M)" was used as the second opening theme to the anime "[Eureka Seven](https://anilist.co/anime/237/Koukyoushihen-Eureka-Seven/)". Their first full-length album "Rock the World" was released the same year as the anime, while also entering the Oricon charts and managing to peak at the 5th spot, while also staying in the top 20 for the next eight weeks. As a summary, the album sold 191,744 copies and became the 78th best selling album of 2005.

After their first album, the group went on several tours and concomitantly released several singles. They also released their second and third albums, "Musication" on February 15, 2006 and "Familia" on March 14, 2007.

On another note, the tickets to their second tour were sold out within the span of one hour, which set a record in Japanese music. In January of 2007, it was announced that they would perform the first ending theme to the anime [Naruto Shippuden](https://anilist.co/anime/1735/Naruto-Shippuuden/), otherwise known as "[Nagareboshi Shooting Star](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q9cT5EAEGyk)". This single entered the Oricon charts and peaked at 10th place. Later on one of their members, Micro, was featured on the Abingdon Boys School song "[Lost Reason](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tO7-lu_wMMo)" as it appeared on their self-titled album.

Home Made Kazoku has performed for a promotional commercial for a product called "Walky Walky" with their song "Easy Walk". In addition, Home Made Kazoku's single, "[No Rain No Rainbow](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TqTLw-GKG5A)", was chosen to be the movie theme for the second Naruto Shippuden movie, respectively titled [Naruto: Shippuden - Kizuna](https://anilist.co/anime/4437/Naruto-Shippuuden-Movie--Kizuna/). Then later in 2011, Home Made Kazoku returned to Naruto Shippuden for the third time with the song "[FREEDOM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wt8XWVon9_w)", which was used as the 17th ending theme.

In their official blog on August 2016 the trio stated that they would go on an indefinite hiatus by the end of the year. According to the comment by group member Micro, the group is taking a hiatus to "grow individually and take on new challenges." The group's three members will then pursue solo careers.

__Members:__
- MICRO (real name 新美太祐, Taisuke Niimi) - MC, in-charge of lyrics and composition
- KURO (real name 水谷Samuel聡史, Satoru Samuel Mizutani) - MC, in-charge of lyrics and composition
- U-ICHI (real name 竹本裕一, Yuuichi Takemoto) - DJ, founding member and in-charge of lyrics and composition

__Former Members:__
- HOZE (1996-2001) - MC

(Source: [Wikipedia (Home Made Kazoku)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Home_Made_Kazoku), edited)

HALCALI is a Japanese rap-pop duo from Meguro, Tokyo. Its two members, Haruka (Halca) and Yukari (Yucali) also comprise the group’s name; a concatenation of "Haru" and "kari." Haruka, born April 21, 1988 and Yukari, born July 18, 1987 originally met as finalists at a hip-hop audition held in a local school in the Meguro district, where both were born.  At their inception, the girls were produced by Oshare Track Factory (OTF) comprised of producing artists RIP SLYME, RYO-Z and DJ Fumiya and signed to Tokyo-based record label, For-Life Music Entertainment (FLME).  (Source: last.fm)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E6%9D%91%E6%9C%A8%E9%9D%96)

Yasushi Muraki is an animator and an occasional director affiliated with [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

Admired [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/) and [Masami Oobari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/), and became an animator. He is skilled in mechanical and action animation, and is one of three animators alongside [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/) and [Masami Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/129865/) who are said to have fully mastered the "Itano Circus" drawing technique. He was invited to join the production of [Eureka Seven](https://anilist.co/anime/237/) by [Kenichi Yoshida](https://anilist.co/staff/103498/), who was in charge of character designs and became the special effects director of the series, fully demonstrating his skills.

(Source: Wikipedia)

Nakamura Koji is a Japanese musician who is most famous for being the lead singer/songwriter of the band Supercar. His music style in general involves drone-like guitar riffs and mixed in raw electronica. He presently records music under the name iLL.  In 2011, Nakamura and former Supercar member Miki Furukawa formed the band LAMA.

(Mecha) designer, occasional writer, for various series.




[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Joey__Jones)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%8B%A5%E6%9E%97%E5%92%8C%E5%BC%98)

**Kazuhiro Wakabayashi** is a Japanese sound director who was formerly affiliated with Techno Sound and Omnibus Promotion. After going freelance, he established his own sound production studio on May 7, 2004 called Fonishia. In 2013, he went freelance once again after his sound production studio disbanded.

A notable mechanical and character designer for both anime and tokusatsu series.

He aspired a career in the industry after having seen [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/), a franchise in which he would eventually serve as a director [in 2012](https://anilist.co/anime/12029/). His career began in 1978, debuting as a mechanical designer on [Toushou Daimos](https://anilist.co/anime/2816/), designing the enemy robots. Few years later in 1981, he made his tokusatsu debut on Robot 8-chan.

The following decade he worked on industry shaping series such as [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/86/), [Macross](https://anilist.co/anime/1089/) and [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/324/). During this time he also had ties to Parallel Creation, a creative group led by sci-fi writer [Aritsune Toyota](https://anilist.co/staff/220367/). This led him to work as an illustrator on novels such as [Record of Lodoss War](https://anilist.co/manga/92655/), in which his designs were deeply influential for Japanese fantasy series.

In 2002, he directed [RahXephon](https://anilist.co/anime/165/), an anime original created by him. Izubuchi said that his attempt was to set a new standard for mecha anime, as well as to bring back aspects of '70s mecha shows like [Brave Raideen](https://anilist.co/anime/2128/).

A trademark in his mechanical designs is the Buchi-hole (ブチ穴), a series of round holes embedded, usually in a cluster pattern of three holes above and two below, located somewhere on the mecha.
[Website](http://www.yanase.works/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yanase_t)

Susumu Yokota (横田 進 Yokota Susumu, or ススム・ヨコタ Susumu Yokota; 1961 – 27 March 2015) was a Japanese composer. He released several albums under pseudonyms including Stevia, Ebi, and others.

Yokota was well known in the English-speaking independent music scene for his albums of experimental ambient music, including albums like Acid Mt. Fuji and Sakura. He also had a long career as a house music DJ and released several highly regarded albums of house music.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/南雅彦) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masahiko_Minami)

A founder and representative director of studio [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/). Also the leading producer of its Studio B.

After graduating from Osaka University of Arts, Minami joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) in 1984. There he did desk work and served as a production assistant on many of [Masuo Ueda](https://anilist.co/staff/148840/)'s productions. He was promoted to producer on [Musha Knight Commando](https://anilist.co/anime/9087/) in 1991, and from there he went on to produce shows such as [Mobile Fighter G Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/96/), [Vision of Escaflowne](https://anilist.co/anime/182/) and [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/). In 1998, he left Sunrise and established Bones with [Toshihiro Kawamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/103531/) and the late [Hiroshi Ousaka](https://anilist.co/staff/107410/). He was elected as the representative director of the studio and has held the position since.

Minami's classmates at university included [Hideaki Anno](https://anilist.co/staff/100111/), [Hiroyuki Yamaga](https://anilist.co/staff/100988/), and [Kazuhiko Shimamoto](https://anilist.co/staff/97479/). He appears as a character in the manga [Aoi Honoo](https://anilist.co/manga/55292/), which Shimamoto wrote about his own university days. The manga also received a TV drama adaptation, in which Minami was portrayed by actor Kaname Endou.

(Source: Wikipedia)

__Birthplace:__ Tokyo, Japan

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%B5%9C%E4%B9%8B%E6%BE%A4%E4%BC%B8)

Shin Unozawa is a planner and producer.

__[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E7%AB%B9%E7%94%B0%E9%9D%91%E6%BB%8B) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seiji_Takeda)__

Seiji Takeda is the deputy director of Mainichi Broadcasting System's Tokyo office.

After graduating from the University of Tokyo's school of literature, Takeda joined Mainichi Broadcasting System in 1984, first working at the network's news bureau and later transferring to the network's Tokyo television department. Among the affairs he had covered during his time in the network's news department was the infamous Glico Morinaga case.

After transferring to MBS' television department, Takeda became involved in the production and planning of numerous anime television series, chiefly starting off the network's Saturday 6:00pm timeblock and being involved in its major popularity and success. Beginning with the timeblock's first major series, [Mobile Suit Gundam SEED](https://anilist.co/anime/93/) and followed by its successors such as [Fullmetal Alchemist](https://anilist.co/anime/121/), [Blood+](https://anilist.co/anime/150/) and [Mobile Suit Gundam 00](https://anilist.co/anime/2581/), the slot has enjoyed high ratings since its inception, with Takeda being involved in the planning and production of each of its shows and having been largely credited for its success. He guest appeared as King T@KED@ in [Mobile Suit Gundam Seed Destiny](https://anilist.co/anime/94/).

Takeda has also been involved in collaborations with the satellite anime television network Animax, with Animax having aired numerous of Mainichi Broadcasting System's anime, as well as jump starting several promotional campaigns in magazines and other media which have helped further promote each of the anime programs aired by the network.

Kawashiro Kazumi is the president & CEO of Bandai Visual. He graduated from Sophia University - a private university in Japan famous for its international climate. In April of 1982, a month after graduation, he started working at Canyon Records. In July of 1989 he joined Bandai and in April of 1994 he was transferred to Bandai Visual of which he became the president of in May of 2003. In 2010, he was succeeded by Ooshita Satoshi, although Kawashiro remained in the company as the vice-president. In April 2012, he was again appointed the president of Bandai Visual.

(Source: AniDB)
